cards.title: Ariana Grande / Doughnut-licking scandal unlikely to derail star on the rise
cards.rawTitle: Doughnut-licking scandal unlikely to derail star on the rise

item.title: Ariana Grande doughnut-licking scandal unlikely to derail star on the rise
item.trailText: Singer’s ‘I hate America’ may be in bad taste, but bad pop star behavior is par for the course – remember, Britney and Miley bounced back
item.standFirst: Singer’s ‘I hate America’ may be in bad taste, but bad pop star behavior is par for the course – remember, Britney and Miley bounced back
item.body:
When Ariana Grande licked a doughnut and said “I hate America,” she did not know the world would watch her do it.

On the Fourth of July, the singer and actress and one of her backup dancers were caught on tape appearing to lick two doughnuts on display in a California shop. Grande was then heard to say: “I hate Americans. I hate America.”

Related: Ariana Grande faces California police inquiry over doughnut-licking incident

After the website TMZ released the video on Tuesday, public reaction was negative. A day later, Grande issued a statement in which she apologised for her words and added that when she said them, she had been upset by America’s obesity rate.

The statement did not bring an end to the scandal. On Wednesday, police in Lake Elsinore, California, and public health officials from Riverside County said they were investigating, while the manager of Wolfee Donuts said the store did not normally leave doughnuts out.

The day after the video was released, MLB Communications tweeted that Grande withdrew as the headliner for the MLB all-star concert because of “health issues”. She will be replaced by Demi Lovato. In a statement Grande wrote that she had “emergency oral surgery” and was still recovering from having her wisdom teeth removed.

Grande, who was born in Boca Raton, Florida, 22 years ago, is known for a string of pop hits, having collaborated with stars such as Nicki Minaj and Jessie J. She began her showbiz career, however, as a child actor, with a role in the Broadway play 13. She went on to play small parts in TV shows such as iCarly and Winx Club: Enchantix.

She then landed the role of Cat Valentine on Nickelodeon’s Victorious, and stayed with the show for three years until it ended. She starred in a spinoff, Sam & Cat, which ended after only 35 episodes, allegedly because of difficulties between Grande and her co-star, Jennette McCurdy.

Grande’s music career began during her time on Victorious, when she signed with Republic Records and released Put Your Hearts Up, a single aimed at young fans of the show. Her real musical debut came in 2013, however, when she released The Way, a single that made it into the top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100 and went triple platinum. The release of a full album, Yours Truly, increased her popularity.

Grande released a second album, My Everything, which reached No1 in the US. She has enjoyed continued success with songs like Problem, Break Free, Bang Bang and Love Me Harder, and is now working on a third album, Moonlight. She will also return to acting this year with a role in Scream Queens, a comedy horror show about vengeance on the anniversary of a sorority pledge gone wrong.

Grande is no stranger to negative press. She has been accused of being demanding at photoshoots and rude to fans. But the doughnut-licking incident has stirred conversation not just among her fans, but other celebrities.

The Oscar-winning actress Susan Sarandon, for example, tweeted: “Today, lick a doughnut in solidarity with @ArianaGrande. A sweet, talented, true American.”

The actor Rob Lowe did not have such a favorable reaction to Grande’s statement. He tweeted: “As my grandpa would say: ‘Yeah, sure. Pull the other leg, it plays jingle bells!’ #Lame”.

Female stars from Madonna to Britney Spears and Miley Cyrus have come back from far bigger controversies – so Grande’s career may not have been licked just yet.

cards.title: Sarah Boseley / Guardian health editor wins consumer media award
cards.rawTitle: Guardian health editor wins consumer media award

item.title: Guardian health editor Sarah Boseley wins consumer media award
item.trailText: Medical Journalists’ Association give Boseley award for second year running for her coverage of issues including Ebola epidemic
item.standFirst: Medical Journalists’ Association give Boseley award for second year running for her coverage of issues including Ebola epidemic
item.body:
Sarah Boseley, the Guardian’s health editor, has won the staff journalist consumer media award from the Medical Journalists’ Association for a second year running.

Boseley’s coverage of issues such as the Ebola epidemic was praised by judges who described her writing as “unusual and of a consistently high standard”.

Olivia Timbs, former editor of the Pharmaceutical Journal and a judge for the prize, said: “Her contributions ranged from an analysis of the use of ketamine that helped the international lobby prevent any restrictions in its use to a piece about the tribulations of launching a clinical trial during the Ebola epidemic … The judges all agreed: she gives you a sense of adventure.”

Commended in the same category were Steve Connor of the Independent and Andrew Gregory of the Daily Mirror.

Among the other winners were the BBC’s Nick Triggle, blogger of the year; Matthew Hill of BBC Points West, regional journalist of the year; and Will Hazell of Health Service Journal, young journalist of the year. The award for a staff journalist writing for a specialist audience went to Helen Thomson of New Scientist. Editor of the year went to Jenni Middleton of Nursing Times.

cards.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger / They ‘screwed up’ Predator franchise

item.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger: they 'screwed up' Predator franchise
item.trailText: Arnold Schwarzenegger tells online forum that ‘greedy’ studios rushed through sequel to his alien hunter thriller
item.standFirst: Arnold Schwarzenegger tells online forum that ‘greedy’ studios rushed through sequel to his alien hunter thriller – and his is the best film in the whole series
item.body:
Arnold Schwarzenegger has given the sequels to his 1987 blockbuster Predator a skinning, saying the follow-up films – neither of which starred him – were not “satisfactory to the audience”.

When asked in a Q and A hosted by Reddit whether he would consider appearing in an upcoming franchise reboot helmed by Iron Man 3 director Shane Black, Schwarzenegger revealed that he has “not been asked”, but that Black’s talents as a “great” writer and director would ensure that “it would become a great movie”, even without his involvement. He went on to describe the first Predator as his “absolute favourite” of the series, and criticised the latter films implying that the the studios rushed them in order to make a quick buck.

“The sad story is that sometimes studios do a great job with creating sequels, and sometimes they really screw it up bad, and it all has to do with greed,” he said. “They sometimes want to do it really cheap and make as much money as possible, so they don’t hire the right cast or the right director.”

Schwarzenegger presumably does not feel the same way about the latest instalment of the Terminator franchise. In Terminator Genisys he again returns to his best-known role as the titular cyborg, although that film has been received largely negatively by critics.

Related: Terminator Genisys review: Arnie's back, but the lustre isn't

He has never shown the same devotion for the Predator franchise since starring in the original back in 1987, and turned down the offer to appear in 1990’s Predator 2 due to a salary dispute. The series has continued in his absence, spawning Predators in 2010, Alien vs. Predator in 2004 and Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem in 2007.

cards.title: Amanda Peterson / Patrick Dempsey and Neil Patrick Harris pay tribute
cards.rawTitle: Patrick Dempsey and Neil Patrick Harris pay tribute

item.title: Patrick Dempsey and Neil Patrick Harris pay tribute to Amanda Peterson
item.trailText: Can’t Buy Me Love co-star and Oscars host take to Twitter to remember late actor, as her mother dismisses talk of daughter’s struggles with drugs
item.standFirst: Can’t Buy Me Love co-star and Oscars host take to Twitter to remember late actor, as her mother dismisses talk of daughter’s struggles with drugs
item.body:
The actor Patrick Dempsey has joined those paying tribute to the late Amanda Peterson, his co-star in the 1980s romantic comedy Can’t Buy Me Love, via Twitter.

Dempsey, best known for films such as Made of Honour and Enchanted, said he would remember the young actor as she had appeared in Steve Rash’s 1987 film.

Related: Amanda Peterson, star of Can’t Buy Me Love, dies aged 43

The pair were star names in Hollywood following the release of Can’t Buy Me Love, a high school rom-com in the vein of John Hughes’s celebrated oeuvre, which centres on a teenage nerd who pays a popular student $1,000 (£647) to act as his girlfriend for a month. While Dempsey has had an enduring career on the big and small screens, Peterson retired from acting more than two decades ago at the age of 23. She was just 16 when Can’t Buy Me Love was filmed.

The Oscars ceremony host Neil Patrick Harris, who starred with the actor in the 1990s TV show Doogie Howser MD, said Peterson had been a great help during the early stages of his career. Meredith Salenger, who appeared alongside Peterson in the 1982 musical Annie, tweeted photographs of the pair together at that time.

The mother of two was found alone at her home in an apartment complex in Greeley, Colorado on 5 July. The actor’s father told the website TMZ that Peterson suffered from sleep apnea, with pneumonia and sinusitis also cited among her recent health issues.

Related: Amanda Peterson: a career in clips

People magazine reported this week that Peterson struggled with drug abuse following the end of her Hollywood career, describing her as “troubled” and publishing police arrest photos. But the actor’s mother, Sylvia, told Entertainment Tonight that those problems were well in the past.

“Amanda was in very good spirits,” she said of the pair’s last meeting. “This was not, in any way, a drug thing.”

Sylvia also told People: “She was in bed, and she’d had a wonderful day, and we were planning on a dinner the next day. So it was just a very, very big surprise.

“She was so great. She had a cute sense of humour and a love of history – just a very, very cute person.”

cards.title: Phil Rudd / AC/DC drummer sentenced to home detention for threat to kill
cards.rawTitle: AC/DC drummer sentenced to home detention for threat to kill

item.title: Phil Rudd, AC/DC drummer, sentenced to home detention for threat to kill
item.trailText: Rudd’s lawyer says conviction would leave musician unable to travel with the band but judge says: ‘Queen replaced Freddie Mercury’
item.standFirst: Rudd’s lawyer says conviction would leave musician unable to travel with the band but judge says: ‘Queen replaced Freddie Mercury’
item.body:
AC/DC drummer Phil Rudd has been sentenced in New Zealand to eight months of home detention after pleading guilty to threatening to kill a man who used to work for him, along with possession of methamphetamine and marijuana.

The 61-year-old drummer was sentenced in Tauranga district court on New Zealand’s North Island on Thursday. He had faced up to seven years in prison on the threatening to kill charge.

Rudd pleaded guilty to the charges in April, acknowledging in a court summary of facts that he had offered large amounts of cash, vehicles and a house to an associate after asking him to have the victim “taken out”.

He also acknowledged that he had directly said to the victim he was going to kill him.

Judge Thomas Ingram told Rudd, 61, he needed to rehabilitate himself from drugs if he wanted to return to rock band AC/DC.

Rudd will be electronically monitored at his Tauranga waterside mansion and must also complete a rehabilitation program.

Ingram told Rudd there “was nowhere to hide” and he would be jailed if he was found with any traces of drugs or alcohol in his system.

Until Rudd rehabilitated himself from a longstanding meth addiction, a future with the band was unlikely, the judge said.

“You are a man that clearly has rehabilitative needs,” he said.

Rudd’s lawyer, Craig Tuck, argued for a discharge without conviction, saying a conviction would leave Rudd unable to travel to Japan, Canada and the US with the band, resulting in the loss of tens of millions of dollars.

Tuck said Rudd’s actions were the result of methamphetamine psychosis.

But Judge Ingram said Rudd had been discharged twice before, on assault and cannabis charges, and there was no evidence to suggest he was with the band any more.

The judge was not convinced Rudd’s drumming was integral to the AC/DC sound. “Queen replaced Freddie Mercury,” Judge Ingram said.

cards.title: Star Wars spin-off / Should Aaron Paul play Han Solo?
cards.rawTitle: Should Aaron Paul play Han Solo?

item.title: Star Wars spin-off: should Aaron Paul play Han Solo – and what about the plot?
item.trailText: Should the younger take on the iconic space smuggler be fresh-faced or early-stage world-weary? How did he meet Chewie and why did he fall out with Jabba? Five key questions for the directors of the new Star Wars spin-off
item.standFirst: Should the younger take on the iconic space smuggler be fresh-faced or early-stage world-weary? How did he meet Chewie and why did he fall out with Jabba? Five key questions for the directors of the new Star Wars spin-off
item.body:
Related: The Lego Movie writer/directors: ‘We wanted to make an anti-totalitarian movie for kids'

You wait a month for more Star Wars spin-off movie news to be announced and then two bombshells come along at once. First: Darth Vader might be set to return in Gareth Edwards’s Rogue One. And second: Lego Movie writer-directors Christopher Miller and Phil Lord are to take on the long-mooted Han Solo movie.

Of all the films set within the wider Star Wars universe which Disney-owned Lucasfilm is now developing, this one looks the most exciting – and the most high stakes. Here are five key questions Miller and Lord need to answer before the cameras roll.

How old should Solo be, and who should play him?

Related: Mad Max’s Nicholas Hoult on hanging off lorries and channeling Andrex puppies

Reports suggest that Lord and Miller’s take will be an origins story, and Star Wars lore reckons Solo was around 29 during the events of the first movie, so it’s perhaps unsurprising that Hollywood sites have been pushing young twentysomethings such as Taron Egerton (25), Ansel Elgort (21) and Nicholas Hoult (25) for the role of the iconic space smuggler. Yet Ford himself was 33 when he began filming Star Wars, his seniority over Mark Hamill (Luke Skywalker) and Carrie Fisher (Princess Leia) giving Solo an essential wily world-weariness. And there’s something about the idea of a fresh-faced take on the Corellian scoundrel that jars.

If Disney-owned Lucasfilm is looking to ape the success of Marvel with its plan for a Star Wars cinematic universe, it should bear in mind that its sister studio has generally plumped for seasoned actors over callow ingenues when casting iconic heroes. Picking an act in their early 30s, perhaps playing a few years younger, would allow Solo to retain just enough of his “been around the block” swagger to keep him recognisable to fans. If Aaron Paul (35 and bookies’ favourite), Taylor Kitsch (34) and Chris Pratt (36) are just too old for the role – well they’d still make better choices than those previously mentioned. Paul, at least, seems more than keen, and someone at Star Wars – even if it’s just the social media editor – is evidently interested.

Then again, the American actor just doesn’t look like a Han Solo type to me, though perhaps I’m being swayed by hours of watching him as a whiny meth addict in Breaking Bad. Second-favourite Aaron Taylor-Johnson has the right mix of brawn and swagger, and is capable of playing older than his 25 years.

How did Han and Chewbacca meet?

Related: Behind the scenes of Star Wars – in pictures

Since the Wookiee co-pilot of the Millennium Falcon is more than 200 years old during the events of the original trilogy, it stands to reason that he and Solo were not always friends. Expanded-universe novels about the smuggler suggest he met his eventual sidekick while working as a pilot on an Imperial slave ship. After he refuses orders to flay the wookiee, Solo and his new pal escape with the help of rebels and the hairy eight-foot-tall humanoid swears a life debt to his saviour. Disney is highly unlikely to borrow too much from the non-canonical books, but Lord and Miller will surely take the chance to bring back one of the saga’s best-known heroes, and explain why he displays such selfless loyalty to Solo. See also: How did Han meet Lando Calrissian and successfully prise the Falcon from his old pal’s possession.

Why does Solo hate the Force?

Han displays a determined scorn for Jedi-like behaviour in the events of the original trilogy. Again, the expanded universe has an answer here, suggesting that the young Solo was once the victim of a religious fraud which left him a distinct non-believer in regard to spiritual matters. The smart route for Lord and Miller would be to avoid delving too deep into such matters: it’s enough for us to know that the Jedi were almost extinct at the beginning of 1977’s Star Wars, so it would hardly be rare for more cynical citizens of the galaxy to view their supposed powers as the stuff of myth and legend. We do, however, need to know how Solo became so world-weary in the first place.

How did Han upset Jabba the Hutt?

George Lucas’s decision to include a CGI version of the corpulent alien in the 1997 special edition of Star Wars will always go down as one of the most misguided film-making decisions ever to rear its ugly head in Hollywood. And Miller and Lord will presumably think carefully before introducing their own youthful, perambulatory version of the iconic gangster. Nevertheless, we know from the original movies that Solo owes a large debt to Jabba that he is either unwilling or unable to pay before being captured by Darth Vader’s forces in Cloud City and transported to the repugnant alien’s Tatooinese lair. Surely the origins of this storyline will play some part in the new film.

Did Han really make the Kessel Run in 12 parsecs, and what does that even mean?

Related: Star Wars: The Force Awakens trailer – a return to the series' strengths

Solo’s boast at the beginning of 1977’s Star Wars can be read in a number of ways. Since a parsec is a unit of distance, rather than time, the smuggler may simply have been talking a load of nonsense in order to secure the patronage of Obi-Wan Kenobi and Luke Skywalker for their trip to Alderaan. George Lucas has said the apparent paradox of a ship covering an 18 parsec route without travelling the full distance can be explained by the Falcon’s advanced navigational computer rather than its engines, which allow it to calculate a smarter route. The expanded universe picks up on the anomaly, suggesting the route itself skirted a cluster of black holes, with Solo managing to cut down his travel time by flying dangerously close to the cosmic bodies. Now wouldn’t that make a scene to rival Han’s romp through the Hoth asteroid field in The Empire Strikes Back?

cards.title: Piers Morgan / From roaring 20s to roaring 50s

item.title: Piers Morgan: from roaring 20s to roaring 50s
item.trailText: Former CNN presenter and Daily Mirror editor celebrates his half century in typically understated style with a Great Gatsby-themed party
item.standFirst: Former CNN presenter and Daily Mirror editor celebrates his half century in typically understated style with a Great Gatsby-themed party
item.body:
Piers Morgan isn’t exactly known for being the shy, retiring type – so a Great Gatsby-themed 50th birthday party seems entirely in character.

Synchronised swimmers, Folies Bergere-style dance troupe, boaters, white suits and more than few celebs joined Morgan at his house on Sunday. Lord Sugar was there (he made a speech), as was Susanna Reid, Charlotte Hawkins, Kate Garraway, Myleene Klass and Amanda Holden.

Also in attendance were Financial Times editor Lionel Barber, journalist and author Tony Parsons, Morgan’s successor at the helm of the Mirror, Richard Wallace, and Matt Kelly of Local World.

Related: Piers Morgan criticised for laughing as Good Morning Britain guest swore on air

Morgan snapped Anthony McPartlin of Ant and Dec fame trying to skim a golf ball across the swimming pool.

And of course no prizes for guessing which character Morgan played. Though swap that suit for a bathrobe and he’d look more comfortable in the Playboy mansion.
